text:
‘And here I am again, doing the same thing,’ Raskolnikov said, feeling a bit uneasy and surprised by the old woman’s distrust. ‘Maybe she’s always like this, but I didn’t notice it last time,’ he thought, feeling uncomfortable.

The old woman hesitated for a moment, then moved aside and pointed to the door of the room, saying, ‘Please come in, sir.’

The small room Raskolnikov entered had yellow paper on the walls, geraniums, and muslin curtains at the windows. It was brightly lit by the setting sun.

‘So the sun will shine like this too!’ Raskolnikov suddenly thought, quickly looking around the room to remember how it was arranged. But there wasn’t anything special in the room. The old yellow wooden furniture included a sofa with a big bent back, an oval table in front of it, a dressing table with a mirror between the windows, chairs along the walls, and a few cheap prints in yellow frames showing German girls with birds. In one corner, a light was burning in front of a small icon. Everything was very clean; the floor and furniture were shiny, and there was not a speck of dust anywhere.

‘Lizaveta must have cleaned this,’ the young man thought.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov visits an old woman to pawn something, feeling uneasy about her mistrust and observing the cleanliness of her modest flat.
